Description: BATES CREEK PRESERVE

THE LANDSCAPE IN WHICH THE PLAYA LAKES JOINT VENTURE (PLJV) PARTNERSHIP FUNCTIONS IS OFTEN REFERRED TO AS THE BREADBASKET OF NORTH AMERICA. IN THE PAST, THIS PHRASE MOSTLY REFERRED TO AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION THAT FED THE WORLD. TODAY, HOWEVER, THE BREADBASKET HAS BEEN EXPANDED TO INCLUDE MINING AND SELLING OF WATER, WIND AND SOLAR DEVELOPMENT, OIL AND GAS DEVELOPMENT, TRANSPORTATION, BIOFUELS, AND HABITAT RESTORATION FOR ENDANGERED AND ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES. AT THE SAME TIME, THE DEMAND FOR FOOD AND FIBER HAS ACCELERATED, CLIMATE CHANGES ARE TAKING EFFECT, AND CONCERNS OVER GROUNDWATER AND AQUIFER DEPLETION GROW.WATER, AS IT RELATES TO WILDLIFE, IS A PRIORITY FOR ALL, BUT WITH OUR EMPHASIS ON WATER AND AQUIFER RECHARGE IT SEEMS TO BE AN ESPECIALLY POWERFUL DRIVER IN FURTHERING PLAYA CONSERVATION. SPECIFICALLY, SOCIAL SCIENCE LEARNING IS NEEDED IN DEALING WITH 1) PROTECTING AND ENHANCING SOURCE WATER FOR FARMS, RANCHES AND TOWNS, 2) AGRICULTURAL TRANSITION, AND 3) IMPROVING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED TO PRODUCERS FOR PLAYA MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION.WE BELIEVE SOCIAL SCIENCE HAS PROVEN INCREASINGLY CRITICAL TO CONSERVATION DELIVERY AND RESPECTFULLY REQUEST ADDITIONAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF  50,000 TO SUPPORT THE SOCIAL SCIENCE LEAD POSITION AND ASSOCIATED COSTS TO 1) FIND AND TRANSLATE EXISTING SOCIAL SCIENCE IN SUPPORT OF THE PARTNERSHIPS WORK  2) CONDUCT APPLIED RESEARCH ACTIVITIES (NOT ACADEMIC RESEARCH) TO ANSWER IMMEDIATE AND PRESSING QUESTIONS  AND 3) MANAGE AN ADVISORY TEAM COMPOSED OF EXPERTS FROM UNIVERSITIES, OTHER INITIATIVES, AND AGENCIES THAT WILL HELP GUIDE AND INFORM THE WORK. THE SOCIAL SCIENCE LEAD HAS AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN SERVING ON NATIONAL WORKING GROUPS, SUCH AS NABCI ANDNAWMP HUMAN DIMENSIONS COMMITTEES, AND ALL WORK UNDER THIS POSITION WILL CONTINUE TO BE HIGHLY APPLIED USING ESTABLISHED HUMAN DIMENSIONS TECHNIQUES, INCLUDING SURVEYS, FOCUS GROUPS, AND INTERVIEWS TO HELP ANSWER THE PARTNERSHIPS QUESTIONS.THE SOCIAL SCIENCE LEAD HAS A SIGNIFICANT LEADERSHIP ROLE IN PLJVS SIX -STATE PARTNERSHIP. IT CONTINUES TO GUIDE AND ADVISE PLJV STAFF AND PARTNERS ON HOW TO APPLY SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH TO DELIVER HABITAT CONSERVATION AND INTEGRATES WITH OTHER PLJV DEPARTMENTS INCLUDING BIOLOGICAL SCIENCE, HABITAT DELIVERY, GIS, COMMUNICATIONS, AND FINANCE.PRINCIPALLY, THIS LEVEL OF CAPACITY PROVIDES IMMEDIATE ACCESS TO  AND BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF  EXISTING SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH PERTAINING TO BIRD HABITAT CONSERVATION IN THE REGION. SECONDLY, THE DAY-TO-DAY WORK OF THE PARTNERSHIP IS INFORMED BY A TRAINED SOCIAL SCIENCE PROFESSIONAL WHO IS HELPING TO GUIDE OUR CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN A PREDOMINANTLY PRIVATE LANDSCAPE. AND FINALLY, THE PARTNERSHIP IS ABLE TO CONDUCT ITS OWN APPLIED SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH FOCUSED ON THE NUANCES OF PLAYA, GRASSLAND, AND RIPARIAN CONSERVATION AND CONSERVATION DELIVERY, PARTICULARLY AS IT RELATES TO SUSTAINABLE FARMING AND GROUNDWATER RECHARGE (BOTH OF WHICH ARE HIGHLY RELEVANT TO OUR SOCIETY AND DECISION-MAKERS).

ABUNDANCE OF MIDCONTINENT SNOW GEESE INCREASED RAPIDLY FROM THE 1980S TO 2000S BUT SINCE ABOUT 2010 HAS DECLINED AT A GREATER RATE THAN THE FORMER INCREASE. THE POPULATION DECLINE IS BELIEVED TO BE DUE TO POOR REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, NOT DECLINING ADULT SURVIVAL, BUT PATTERNS IN THESE DEMOGRAPHIC RATES WITHIN AND AMONG SUBPOPULATIONS HAVE NOT BEEN EVALUATED IN A HOLISTIC MODELING FRAMEWORK. SUCH A FRAMEWORK WOULD IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING ABOUT WHETHER (I) SURVIVAL, REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS AND OR MOVEMENTS ARE SIMILAR AMONG SUBPOPULATIONS (SUGGESTING SYNCHRONY IN RESPONSE TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, WHETHER ACROSS THE ARCTIC AND SUBARCTIC OR ON MIGRATION AND WINTER AREAS) OR (II) SPECIFIC SUBPOPULATIONS HAVE DIFFERENT DEMOGRAPHIC RATES (SUGGESTING VARYING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS OR BIRD RESPONSES TO THEM). WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED METAPOPULATION MODEL (IMM) FOR MIDCONTINENT ARCTIC AND SUBARCTIC SNOW GEESE REPRESENTING FIVE SUBPOPULATIONS, USING ALL AVAILABLE DEMOGRAPHIC AND POPULATION SURVEY INFORMATION TO ESTIMATE DEMOGRAPHIC RATES AND ABUNDANCES, AND IDENTIFY MECHANISMS THAT INFLUENCE DEMOGRAPHIC PROCESSES, WITHIN AND AMONG SUBPOPULATIONS. WE WILL USE THE IMM TO CONDUCT HYPOTHESIS TESTS ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS OF WITHIN AND AMONG COLONY VARIATION IN POPULATION DYNAMICS. WE BELIEVE THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE A FLEXIBLE FRAMEWORK THAT OTHER RESEARCHERS COULD USE AND ADAPT, ACCORDING TO THEIR SPECIFIC RESEARCH QUESTIONS. THESE PRODUCTS WILL CONTRIBUTE SUBSTANTIALLY TOWARD ONGOING ASSESSMENT OF MIDCONTINENT SNOW GOOSE DYNAMICS, WHICH COULD INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND CONSERVATION PLANNING.

SINCE THE 1970S, LESSER SNOW GOOSE MANAGEMENT IN THE PACIFIC FLYWAY HAS RELIED ON DEMOGRAPHIC AND POPULATION SURVEY DATA COLLECTED DURING SUMMER ON ARCTIC BREEDING AREAS AND WITHIN VARIOUS WINTERING AREAS. WHILE THERE HAVE BEEN SEVERAL PREVIOUS EFFORTS TO QUANTIFY ABUNDANCE, HARVEST, AND DEMOGRAPHIC RATES OF WRANGEL ISLAND POPULATION (WIP) AND WESTERN ARCTIC POPULATION (WAP) LESSER SNOW GEESE, DETERMINING THE MECHANISM(S) FOR POPULATION CHANGE HAS BEEN DIFFICULT BECAUSE THESE POPULATIONS COMINGLE IN STAGING AND WINTERING AREAS, WHICH CREATES CHALLENGES FOR OBTAINING POPULATION-SPECIFIC DATA AND ESTIMATES, AND THERE HAVE BEEN GAPS IN OPERATIONAL MONITORING. THESE LIMITATIONS REQUIRE A COMPREHENSIVE MODELING FRAMEWORK THAT ACCOUNTS FOR, AND LEVERAGES MULTIPLE DATA SETS, TO ACCURATELY ESTIMATE DEMOGRAPHY OF EACH POPULATION. ALSO, THERE IS SUBSTANTIAL UNCERTAINTY ABOUT FUTURE MONITORING OF WIP AND WAP LESSER SNOW GEESE. DEVELOPMENT OF A MODELING FRAMEWORK THAT ESTIMATES THE DEMOGRAPHIC MECHANISM(S) FOR POPULATION CHANGE AND IDENTIFIES THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS OF DEMOGRAPHIC DATA SETS WOULD BE VERY USEFUL TO GUIDE FUTURE INVESTMENTS IN MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF LESSER SNOW GOOSE POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT THE PACIFIC FLYWAY. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED POPULATION MODEL FOR WIP AND WAP LESSER SNOW GEESE USING ALL AVAILABLE DEMOGRAPHIC AND POPULATION SURVEY INFORMATION TO ESTIMATE DEMOGRAPHIC RATES AND ABUNDANCES, AND IDENTIFY MECHANISMS THAT INFLUENCE DEMOGRAPHICS PROCESSES FOR THESE POPULATIONS. THE IPM WILL BE USED TO EVALUATE THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF EACH DATA SET TOWARD DEMOGRAPHIC ESTIMATION AND PRIORITIZE FUTURE MONITORING STRATEGIES THAT WILL ENABLE PRACTITIONERS TO MAKE INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS (E.G., ABOUT ESTABLISHING POPULATION OBJECTIVES, MONITORING AND HARVEST). THESE PRODUCTS WILL ESTABLISH THE FOUNDATION TO DEVELOP EFFECTIVE MONITORING PROGRAMS AND A METAPOPULATION MODEL LINKING LESSER SNOW GOOSE ARCTIC BREEDING COLONIES AND WINTERING AREAS FOR MORE HOLISTIC MANAGEMENT IN FUTURE YEARS.

WE PROPOSE TO EXPLORE FEATURES OF BLACK DUCK BREEDING BIOLOGY AND HABITAT USE, WITH RESULTS THAT WILL DIRECTLY AND IMMEDIATELY BENEFIT OUR EXISTING WORK STUDYING BLACK DUCKS THROUGHOUT THE FULL ANNUAL CYCLE. WE PROPOSE TO HIRE A POSTDOCTORAL FELLOW TO LEAD THIS WORK AND BUILD ON THE EXISTING INTEGRATED POPULATION MODEL (IPM) FOR BLACK DUCKS BY STRUCTURALLY LINKING DEMOGRAPHIC PROCESSES WITH INDIVIDUAL PROCESSES, TO TEST HYPOTHESES ABOUT REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS AND SURVIVAL AT MULTIPLE SCALES SIMULTANEOUSLY. OUR OBJECTIVES ARE:1. DEPLOY 104 GPS-ACC TRACKING DEVICES ON BLACK DUCKS DURING WINTER IN THE MISSISSIPPI FLYWAY, SPLIT ACROSS THE NEXT TWO YEARS.2. ADAPT MACHINE LEARNING ALGORITHMS TO IDENTIFY BREEDING PROPENSITY AND BROOD-REARING, BASED ON LIBRARIES DEVELOPED FOR FULL-TERM INCUBATION FOR GREATER CONFIDENCE IN ALL THREE REPRODUCTIVE PERIOD METRICS.3. EXAMINE AVAILABLE SPACE AND TIME SCALES OF COVARIATE DATA IN THE BOREAL FOREST DURING SUMMER THAT COULD EXPLAIN VARIATION IN BLACK DUCK MOVEMENTS AND BEHAVIOR, AS WELL AS REPRODUCTIVE METRICS.4. INTEGRATE BLACK DUCK DEMOGRAPHY WITH INFORMATION ABOUT MOVEMENTS, BEHAVIOR, SURVIVAL AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS FROM GPS-ACC TRACKING DEVICES, FOR HOLISTIC HYPOTHESIS TESTS OF POPULATION AND INDIVIDUAL PROCESSES AND MORE INFORMED CONSERVATION PLANNING.5. USE THE MODIFIED IPM TO CONDUCT SCENARIO-PLAYING ABOUT THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS OF SURVEY, BANDING, AND GPSACC DATA TOWARD DEMOGRAPHIC ESTIMATES.RESULTS FROM THIS WORK WILL BETTER INFORM OUR UNDERSTANDING OF BLACK DUCK BREEDING BIOLOGY AND DRIVERS, WITH LINKS TO OTHER PARTS OF THE ANNUAL CYCLE. WE ALSO ANTICIPATE THAT LINKING  INDIVIDUAL AND POPULATION PROCESSES WILL PROVIDE A MORE HOLISTIC FRAMEWORK TO TEST FUTURE HYPOTHESES ABOUT BLACK DUCK MOVEMENTS, BEHAVIOR, SURVIVAL AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, AND ALLOW OTHER PRACTITIONERS TO CUSTOMIZE OUR MODELS FOR THEIR QUESTIONS.

THE WESTERN NEW YORK LAND CONSERVANCY IS SEEKING FUNDING TO PERMANENTLY PROTECT THE 223-ACRE DEMINK FOREST. THIS RICH FOREST AND WETLAND COMPLEX IS LOCATED ADJACENT TO THE 168-ACRE COLLEGE LODGE FOREST, WHICH WAS PRESERVED IN PART THROUGH FUNDING FROM THE GLRI  JOINT VENTURE HABITAT RESTORATION AND PROTECTION PROGRAM. THE DEMINK PROJECT PERMANENTLY PROTECTS SEVERAL BCR 13 PRIORITY HABITATS, INCLUDING 55.39 ACRES OF FORESTED WETLAND   SCRUB-SHRUB WETLAND, 6.55 ACRES OF OPEN WATER   EMERGENT WETLAND, AND 162 ACRES OF DECIDUOUS   MIXED FOREST. THE LAND CONSERVANCY IS A REGIONAL, NOT-FOR-PROFIT LAND TRUST THAT HAS HELPED PROTECT MORE THAN 7,500 ACRES OF LAND WITH SIGNIFICANT CONSERVATION VALUES IN WESTERN NEW YORK, OWNS 23 PROPERTIES IN FEE, HOLDS CONSERVATION EASEMENTS ON 59 OTHER PROPERTIES, AND HAS HELPED OTHER ORGANIZATIONS AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS PROTECT 16 OTHER PROPERTIES.PERMANENTLY PROTECTING DEMINK FOREST BY PURCHASING 223 ACRES OF PROPERTY IS AN INTERNATIONAL PRIORITY. THE LAND IS PART OF A LARGE COMPLEX OF SOME OF THE MOST EXQUISITE NATURAL AREAS REMAINING IN WESTERN NEW YORK. IT IS HOME TO HEALTHY FORESTS, PRISTINE WETLANDS, AND RARE AND PROTECTED PLANTS AND ANIMALS. THE PROPERTY SITS IN A CRITICAL PLACE ALONG A BIRD MIGRATORY FLYWAY AND IT SUPPORTS IMPORTANT SPECIES OF MIGRATORY AND NESTING BIRDS. DEMINK IS A LINKAGE AREA BEST PATH OF THE WESTERN NEW YORK WILDWAY, AND SITS ADJACENT TO THE COLLEGE LODGE FOREST, A PROTECTED CORE AREA OF THE WILDWAY. THE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THAT DEMINK PROVIDES CONTRIBUTE TO THE HEALTH OF GREAT LAKES. THE LAND ALSO INCLUDES MILES OF WALKING, CROSS-COUNTRY SKIING, AND SNOW-SHOEING TRAILS, AND IN COMBINATION WITH THE ADJACENT COLLEGE LODGE FOREST, CREATES A RECREATIONAL AND HABITAT COMPLEX OF OVER 400 ACRES. DEMINK FOREST IS CURRENTLY THREATENED AND COULD BE LOST. IF NOT PROTECTED, ITS HEALTHY FORESTS MAY BE LOGGED, AND THE LAND MAY BE SOLD FOR PRIVATE DEVELOPMENT.THE HABITATS AT DEMINK FOREST SUPPORT IMPORTANT WILDLIFE, ESPECIALLY BIRDS. A STUDY OF THE ADJACENT COLLEGE LODGE FOREST BY THE ROGER TORY PETERSON INSTITUTE OF NATURAL HISTORY (RTPI) FROM 2013-2014, AS WELL AS DIRECT OBSERVATION BY LAND CONSERVANCY STAFF, SUGGESTS THAT THE PROPERTY SUPPORTS AT LEAST 146 SPECIES OF BIRDS. THE PROJECT PROTECTS CRITICAL HABITAT FOR BCR 13 TARGET SPECIES DURING RELEVANT LIFE STAGES BY PROVIDING MIGRATORY STOPOVER HABITAT FOR SONGBIRDS, WATERFOWL AND RAPTORS AS WELL AS BREEDING HABITAT FOR 21 CONFIRMED NESTING SPECIES, 50 PROBABLE NESTING SPECIES, AND 20 POSSIBLE NESTING SPECIES.DEMINK FOREST IS PART OF A MOSAIC OF CONSERVED LANDS WHICH INCLUDE THE 168-ACRE COLLEGE LODGE FOREST (PROTECTED THIS YEAR BY THE LAND CONSERVANCY WITH FUNDS FROM THIS SAME PROGRAM), THE 977-ACRE STOCKTON STATE FOREST, THE 2,944-ACRE BOUTWELL HILL STATE FOREST, THE 1,283-ACRE HATCH CREEK STATE FOREST, THE 2,271-ACRE HARRIS HILL STATE FOREST, THE 2,188 ACRE CANADAWAY CREEK STATE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA, THE 355-ACRE LAKE ERIE STATE PARK, THE 360-ACRE LONG POINT STATE PARK, AND SEVERAL NRCS WETLAND RESERVE PROGRAM CONSERVATION EASEMENTS. LAND CONSERVANCY ACQUISITION PROJECTS CATALYZE COMMUNITY SUPPORT FOR CONSERVATION AND LEAD TO ADDITIONAL LAND PROTECTION PROJECTS IN THE SAME COMMUNITY. MUCH OF THE LAND SURROUNDING THE PROPERTY IS FORESTED, PRIVATELY OWNED, AND COULD ALSO BE PROTECTED.

TO FURTHER ITS CONSERVATION MISSION, TILT IS SEEKING FUNDING ASSISTANCE THROUGH THE 2022 GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE   JOINT VENTURE HABITAT RESTORATION AND PROTECTION GRANT (GLRI) TO ALLOW FOR THE PERMANENT PROTECTION OF 295 ACRES OF VITAL HABITAT IN THE ST. LAWRENCE RIVER VALLEY (SLRV), OF WHICH 18 ACRES ARE WETLAND. THE CONSERVATION WILL BE IN THE FORM OF TWO (2) FEE SIMPLE LAND ACQUISITION PROJECTS ON VARYING AND DIVERSE HABITATS OF THE SLRV. GLRI FUNDING WILL BE UTILIZED FOR THE PURCHASE PRICE OF BOTH PROJECTS.

THE JV IS A PARTNERSHIP ESTABLISHED TO IMPLEMENT GOALS OF THE NORTH AMERICAN WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT PLAN (NAWMP),AND IT ENCOMPASSES A CRITICAL GEOGRAPHY FOR WATERFOWL, WATERBIRDS, AND OTHER WETLAND WILDLIFE DURING BREEDING ANDNON BREEDING PERIODS. THE JV REGION ALSO INCLUDES 60 MILLION PEOPLE, MANY OF WHICH DEPEND ON WETLAND FUNCTIONS(E.G., WATER PURIFICATION AND NUTRIENT STORAGE) AND OR ENJOY RECREATIONAL ASPECTS ASSOCIATED WITH WETLANDCOMMUNITIES (E.G., WATERFOWL HUNTING, FISHING, BOATING RECREATION, WILDLIFE OBSERVATION).THE PURPOSE OF THIS FELLOWSHIP PROJECT IS TWO FOLD   ADDRESS A STATED NAWMP NEED FOR TRAINING WHILE RECOGNIZINGTHE LONG TERM CONTRIBUTIONS OF SCIENCE COLLEAGUE DAVID R. LUUKKONEN, PHD. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, WE WILL PARTIALLYFUND 2 4 GRADUATE STUDENT PROJECTS YEAR FOCUSED ON WATERFOWL, WETLANDS, AND OR SOCIAL SCIENCE RELATED TO WETLANDAND WETLAND BIRD CONSERVATION.

THE PRIMARY ROLE OF THE NAWMP 2023 UPDATE U.S CO CHAIR IS TO COORDINATE AND COMMUNICATE PLAN UPDATE ACTIVITIES WITH THE CANADA AND MEXICO UPDATE CO CHAIRS. ADDITIONALLY, THE U.S. CO CHAIR WILL WORK WITH APPROPRIATE USFWS PLAN STAFF TO SELECT 4 ADDITIONAL INDIVIDUALS TO SERVE AS US MEMBERS OF THE PLAN UPDATE COMMITTEE. FURTHER, THE U.S. CO CHAIR WILL LEAD THE U.S. COMMITTEE, AND IN COLLABORATION WITH CANADA AND MEXICO, COORDINATE ACTIVITIES OF NAWMP SUPPORT TEAMS WORK GROUPS COMPRISED OF PARTNER REPRESENTATIVES (HABITAT, POPULATION, SCIENCE, AND NAWPEP) ULTIMATELY LEADING TO COMPLETION OF A DRAFT 2023 NAWMP UPDATE FOR CONSIDERATION AND SUBSEQUENT APPROVAL BY THE PLAN COMMITTEE.
CURRENT AND FUTURE MIGRATION AND WINTER DISTRIBUTION OF FOUR AT-RISK FOREST BIRD SPECIES

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO PUT SCIENCE INTO PRACTICES, HELPING LAND MANAGERS SCALE-UP CONSERVATION DELIVERY TO ADDRESS THE LARGEST THREAT THE SAGEBRUSH BIOME: INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES. CENTERED AROUND THE PROACTIVE  DEFEND AND GROW THE CORE  FRAMEWORK, LEADING EXPERTS IN APPLIED SCIENCE AND MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES WILL EMBARK ON A CAMPAIGN TO EQUIP LAND MANAGERS WITH THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND TOOLS NEEDED TO IMPLEMENT EFFECTIVE INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASS MANAGEMENT.EXPERTS WILL TRANSLATE THE LATEST SCIENCE INTO THE USABLE TECHNICAL MATERIALS, FOSTER EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING THROUGH FIELD WORKSHOPS AND ONLINE MODULES, AND ESTABLISH AN INNOVATIVE MULTI-STATE DEMONSTRATION AND MONITORING NETWORK THAT ENABLES ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT AND ONGOING TECHNICAL SUPPORT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO CONTINUE A LONG-STANDING RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE RWBJV AND THE NEBRASKA COMMUNITY FOUNDATION (NCF).  THIS COLLABORATION WILL UTILIZE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FROM USFWS MIGRATORY BIRDS AND OTHER USFWS DIVISIONS ALONG WITH NCFS FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT SKILLS TO SUPPORT THE RWBJV PARTNERSHIP IN ACHIEVING THE BIRD HABITAT CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN THE RWBJV IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AND ASSOCIATED ANNUAL OPERATION PLAN.  TO SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENT MIGRATORY BIRD HABITAT CONSERVATION THE RWBJV PARTNERSHIP DEVELOPED ITS IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AROUND THE STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION (SHC) FRAMEWORK AND JV MATRIX.  THE RWBJV IMPLEMENTATION PLAN HAS FIVE INTERRELATED CRITICAL ELEMENTS:  JV ADMINISTRATION, BIOLOGICAL PLANNING, CONSERVATION DESIGN, RESEARCH MONITORING EVALUATION, AND IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT DELIVERY.  WHEN THE ELEMENTS OF THIS BUSINESS MODEL ARE IMPLEMENTED, THERE IS A FEEDBACK LOOP THAT REFINES CONSERVATION DELIVERY THROUGH TIME.  THIS AGREEMENT WILL UTILIZE FUNDING TO SUPPORT THESE CRITICAL ELEMENTS.  THIS PROJECT WILL BE INCREMENTAL TO ALLOW FLEXIBILITY AND ENSURE JOINT VENTURE MANAGEMENT BOARD PRIORITIES OUTLINED IN THE ANNUAL OPERATION PLANS CAN BE ACHIEVED THROUGH MULTI-YEAR PROJECTS AS DEFINED IN THE AGREEMENT.  THIS AGREEMENT WILL PROVIDE THE MECHANISM TO LEVERAGE RESOURCES NECESSARY TO COMPLETE COMPLEX PROJECTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE FIVE CORE ELEMENTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE SHC MODEL.    TO ENSURE EFFECTIVE OPERATIONS (JV ADMINISTRATION), FUNDING WILL BE PROVIDED TO SUPPORT OFFICE MANAGEMENT, OVERHEAD, AND GRANT DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION.  NCF STAFF WILL PROVIDE THE CAPACITY TO SUPPORT JV OPERATIONS AND MANAGEMENT.
THIS AGREEMENT WILL PROVIDE FUNDS TO CREATE OR EXPAND WATERFOWL HUNTING AND VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH HABITAT CONSERVATION, KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT, AND YOUTH EVENTS.

CONCERN HAS BEEN GROWING ABOUT DECLINING POPULATIONS OF SECRETIVE MARSH BIRDS IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION, RESULTING IN SEVERAL SPECIES BEING LISTED AS ENDANGERED, THREATENED, AND SPECIAL CONCERN AND BEING CONSIDERED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN MULTIPLE MIDWESTERN STATES. SOME SPECIES WERE ALSO IDENTIFIED AS FOCAL SPECIES FOR HABITAT CONSERVATION WITHIN THE WATERBIRD HABITAT CONSERVATION STRATEGY OF THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI   GREAT LAKES JOINT VENTURE (JV). ALTHOUGH SOME RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES ARE OCCURRING FOR MARSH BIRDS, AN INITIATIVE IS NEEDED TO FOCUS PARTNERS ON THE MOST EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION ACTIONS IN THE MOST IMPORTANT PLACES TO ACHIEVE MEANINGFUL BENEFITS FOR THESE SPECIES. THE MICHIGAN NATURAL FEATURES INVENTORY (MNFI) PROPOSES TO ASSIST THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND JV IN DEVELOPING A GREAT LAKES MARSH BIRD CONSERVATION FRAMEWORK TO FURTHER THE IMPLEMENTATION OF STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION FOR PRIORITY MARSH BIRD SPECIES. PROPOSED FUNDING WOULD SUPPORT TIME FOR THE MNFI STAFF TO WORK WITH THE USFWS PERSONNEL (E.G., MIGRATORY BIRD BIOLOGIST, JV COORDINATOR) AND REGIONAL PARTNERS TO DEVELOP THE FRAMEWORK AND RESULTING PRODUCTS. TASKS WOULD INCLUDE HOLDING AND FACILITATING MEETINGS WITH PARTNERS TO DETERMINE GOALS, OBJECTIVES, AND STRATEGIES FOR THE INITIATIVE, PREPARING DOCUMENTS DETAILING THE FRAMEWORK, DEVELOPING GIS-BASED TOOLS TO FACILITATE CONSERVATION PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION, AND COMMUNICATING INFORMATION ABOUT THE INITIATIVE TO OTHER GROUPS, SUCH AS THE JV SCIENCE TEAM AND GREAT LAKES COASTAL ASSEMBLY.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL SUPPORT ACTIVITIES OUTLINED IN THE CENTRAL VALLEY JOINT VENTURE (CVJV) IMPLEMENTATION PLAN. THESE ACTIONS WILL BE DEVELOPED BY THE CVJV. THE CENTRAL VALLEY HAS BEEN DESIGNATED AS A CRITICAL MIGRATION STOPOVER SITE FOR MIGRATORY WATERFOWL BY THE NORTH AMERICAN WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT PLAN (NAWMP) AND FOR SHOREBIRDS BY THE WESTERN HEMISPHERIC SHOREBIRD RESERVE NETWORK (WHSRN). SINCE SETTLEMENT OVER 90  OF THE CENTRAL VALLEY WETLANDS HAVE BEEN DRAINED OR SIGNIFICANTLY MODIFIED REDUCING WETLAND FUNCTION AND HABITAT VALUE. CURRENT ANALYSIS SUGGESTS THAT WETLAND RESTORATION, MANAGEMENT, AND ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES ARE CRITICAL TO ENSURE THIS REGION WILL ADEQUATELY MEET HABITAT REQUIREMENTS FOR THE MILLIONS OF WATERFOWL AND OTHER WETLAND DEPENDENT SPECIES THAT ANNUALLY USE THIS REGION. THE CENTRAL VALLEY JOINT VENTURE (CVJV) PROVIDES A PARTNERSHIP STRUCTURE FOR AGENCIES, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO ADDRESS NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUES THROUGH PROJECTS THAT IMPROVE MIGRATORY BIRD HABITAT.THE CVJV IS A DIVERSE PARTNERSHIP THAT HAS A PROVEN TRACK RECORD OF LEVERAGING FEDERAL AND NON-FEDERAL FUNDS TO COMPLETE ALL ELEMENTS OF THE STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION (SHC) BUSINESS MODEL. THESE ACTIONS WILL RESULT IN TANGIBLE CONSERVATION DELIVERABLES THAT WILL SUPPORT BIRD CONSERVATION WITHIN THE CENTRAL VALLEY. AS PART OF THIS PARTNERSHIP THE CALIFORNIA WATERFOWL ASSOCIATION (CWA) OVERSEES DISBURSEMENTS, IMPLEMENTS A RIGOROUS PROCUREMENT POLICY TO COMPLY WITH OMB SUPER CIRCULAR REQUIREMENTS, AND ENSURES PROPER AUDITING TO ENSURE PROJECT COMPONENTS ARE WITHIN THE SCOPE OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT AND IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS.

THIS REQUEST IS TO SUPPORT THE MT STATE COORDINATOR (SC) POSITION AT  20,000 YEAR FOR THREE YEARS. THE SC PROVIDES LEADERSHIP, SUPERVISION, AND SUPPORT TO MONTANA BIOLOGIST TEAM WORKING WITHIN THE PPR AND FACILITATES COLLABORATION OF MULTIPLE PARTNERS TO DELIVER LANDSCAPE SCALE CONSERVATION INITIATIVES. WE EXPECT THE SC TO FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF 2 TIPS PER YEAR FOR A TOTAL OF 6 TIPS WITHIN THE PPJV BOUNDARY AND WITH THE PRODUCTION OF 2 SUCCESS STORIES RELATED TO TIP DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION FOR INCLUSION IN THE PPJV NEWSLETTER AND OTHER MEDIA.

TNC WILL SUPPORT THE USFWS EASEMENT PROGRAM IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE JOINT VENTURE BY EMPLOYING TWO CONSERVATION TECHNICIANS - POSITIONS CRITICAL TO ACHIEVING PERMANENT PROTECTION OF THE GLOBALLY UNIQUE, YET HIGHLY THREATENED, GRASSLAND AND WETLAND REMAINING IN EASTERN SOUTH DAKOTA.

SINCE 2000, THE CENTRAL HARDWOODS JOINT VENTURE (CHJV) HAS WORKED TO IMPLEMENT ALL-BIRD CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES AS SET FORTH BY THE VARIOUS NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL BIRD CONSERVATION INITIATIVES OPERATING UNDER THE UMBRELLA OF THE NORTH AMERICAN BIRD CONSERVATION INITIATIVE (NABCI). THE PARTNERSHIP POOLED MONEY TO HIRE A COORDINATOR IN 2001, WITH AMERICAN BIRD CONSERVANCY (ABC) AS THEIR EMPLOYER. ABC HAS EMPLOYED CHJV STAFF AND HANDLED CHJV FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS CONTINUOUSLY SINCE THAT TIME. THE CHJV FOLLOWS THE PRINCIPLES OF STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION AND THE ELEMENTS OF THE JOINT VENTURE MATRIX, FOCUSING ON PRIORITY SPECIES AND POPULATION AND HABITAT GOALS AS SET FORTH BY THE VARIOUS NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL BIRD CONSERVATION INITIATIVES OPERATING WITHIN NABCI.WHILE IMPLEMENTATION RELATED DIRECTLY TO PUTTING HABITAT ON THE GROUND IS LARGELY CONSIDERED THE WORK OF JV PARTNER AGENCIES AND THEIR STAFF, THE FUNDS VIA THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WOULD BE USED TO SUPPORT THE STAFFING AND GENERAL OPERATING COSTS OF CHJV. THE CHJV COORDINATOR OVERSEES THE DAY-TO-DAY OPERATION OF THE CHJV PARTNERSHIP AND SUPERVISES OTHER CHJV STAFF. THE AVIAN ECOLOGIST IS RESPONSIBLE FOR PERFORMING OR COORDINATING RESEARCH, DATA ANALYSES, AND POPULATION HABITAT MODELING  INTERPRETING THE RESULTS OF NEW RESEARCH RELEVANT TO CHJV PRIORITY BIRDS AND COMMUNICATING THIS TO CHJV PARTNERS  AND MONITORING AND EVALUATION EFFORTS RELATED TO BIOLOGICAL PLANNING AND CONSERVATION DESIGN. THE DELIVERY COORDINATOR COMMUNICATES WITH PARTNERS FROM REGIONAL TO LOCAL SCALES TO RELAY CHJV POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES AND HELP FIND WAYS TO ACHIEVE THOSE AS EFFICIENTLY AND EFFECTIVELY AS POSSIBLE. FUNDS AWARDED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT MAY ALSO BE USED TO LEVERAGE OTHER CONTRIBUTIONS TO RESEARCH, MONITORING, COMMUNICATION AND DELIVERY OR IMPLEMENTATION EFFORTS IF AGREED TO BY THE CHJV MANAGEMENT BOARD UNDER THE DICTATES OF ITS OPERATING PRINCIPLES.

THE 2017 PPJV IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AND THE 2022 STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS PLAN OUTLINE DETAILED OBJECTIVES FORACHIEVING THE GOALS OF THE PPJV. WITH THE VAST MAJORITY OF LAND ACROSS THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE REGION HELD IN PRIVATEOWNERSHIP, IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT PPJV PARTNERS BUILD TRUST WITH RANCHERS, FARMERS, AND OTHER PRIVATE LANDOWNERSBY SHOWING HOW MIGRATORY BIRD CONSERVATION AND AGRICULTURE CAN COEXIST AND THRIVE. FROM ITS INCEPTION, THE TRUSTHAS PLAYED A VITAL ROLE AS FACILITATOR BETWEEN AGRICULTURAL AND CONSERVATION INTERESTS IN NORTH DAKOTA. INADDITION TO FACILITATING AND FUNDING SOUND PROJECTS, ITS GOAL IS TO IDENTIFY COMMON ISSUES, CREATE DIALOGUE, ANDRESOLVE CONFLICTS. THE LANDSCAPE OF NORTH DAKOTA IS DOMINATED BY AGRICULTURAL USES, SO DEVELOPING AND MAINTAININGRELATIONSHIPS WITH INDIVIDUAL LANDOWNERS AND WITH AGRICULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS IS BOTH DESIRABLE AND CRITICAL TOTHE CONSERVATION APPROACH PRACTICED BY THE PPJV.GIVEN PAST AND CURRENT WORK UNDERTAKEN BY THE NORTH DAKOTA NATURAL RESOURCES TRUST, THEY CONTINUE TO GAIN ACCESS,TRUST, AND ACCEPTANCE OF PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN NORTH DAKOTA, SO THE PPJV DESIRES TO SUPPORT THE TRUST TO FURTHERCONSERVATION OPPORTUNITIES WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, NAMELY THOSE ENGAGED IN AGRICULTURAL ACTIVITIES. THE PURPOSEOF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO THE NORTH DAKOTA NATURAL RESOURCES TRUST TO ADDRESS ACTIONSIDENTIFIED IN THE 2017 PPJV IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AND THE 2022 PPJV STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS PLAN AS IT BROADLYRELATES TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND MIGRATORY BIRD HABITAT CONSERVATION. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE EFFORTS TO COORDINATEPARTNERSHIPS AND OUTREACH WITH AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS AND ORGANIZATIONS  PARTICIPATE COMPLETE WETLAND ANDGRASSLAND CONSERVATION PROJECTS THROUGH COORDINATION OF PARTNERS  ACTIVELY PARTICIPATE, OR LEAD IF APPROPRIATE,COMMUNICATION EFFORTS IN SUPPORT OF PPJV GOALS AND OBJECTIVES  SUPPORT TOURS, WORKSHOPS AND OUTREACH RELATIVE TOPPJV GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

SEA DUCKS ARE POPULAR WATERFOWL, AND THEY ARE ALSO OF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT CONCERN. THEIR LIFE HISTORY CHARACTERISTICS ARE LESS UNDERSTOOD THAN ARE THOSE OF OTHER WATERFOWL BUT DATA SUGGEST THEY MAY BE VULNERABLE TO OVERHARVEST AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE. EFFORTS TO CONSERVE AND MANAGE SEA DUCKS REQUIRE KNOWLEDGE OF POPULATION DELINEATION AS IT RELATES TO THEIR HARVEST. HOWEVER, SUCH INFORMATION IS OFTEN UNAVAILABLE ACROSS THE LARGE BREEDING-RANGES OF MOST SEA-DUCK SPECIES, PARTICULARLY FOR JUVENILES. A PRIOR SDJV-FUNDED PROJECT INDICATED THAT STABLE HYDROGEN ISOTOPE RATIOS ARE A PROMISING TOOL FOR IDENTIFYING THE BREEDING GROUNDS OF HUNTER-HARVESTED LONG-TAILED DUCKS AND SURF SCOTERS. WE HEREIN PROPOSE TO EXPAND UPON THOSE RESULTS TO ASSESS (1) VARIATION IN THE LOCATION OF BREEDING HABITAT ACROSS FLYWAYS AND (2) THE POTENTIAL OF COASTAL MARINE HABITAT AS FLEDGLING AREAS. SPECIFICALLY, WE PROPOSE TO (1) INCREASE FEATHER SAMPLE SIZES AND FILL GEOGRAPHIC GAPS FOR HUNTER-HARVESTED JUVENILE LONG-TAILED DUCKS AND SURF SCOTERS, (2) STABLE CARBON, NITROGEN, AND SULFUR VALUES TO IDENTIFY BIRDS PROVISIONED FROM TERRESTRIAL FRESHWATER VS. COASTAL MARINE HABITATS DURING THE PERIOD OF FEATHER GROWTH, (3) USE 2H VALUES TO CREATE A LIKELIHOOD-OF-ORIGIN MAP TO IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC AREAS WHERE INDIVIDUALS PROVISIONED FROM TERRESTRIAL FRESHWATER ENVIRONMENTS FLEDGED, (4) EVALUATE HYPOTHESES ABOUT VARIATION IN THE LOCATION OF FLEDGING GROUNDS OF THESE SPECIES AMONG FLYWAYS. TO ACCOMPLISH THESE OBJECTIVES, WE PROPOSE TO MEASURE STABLE HYDROGEN, CARBON, NITROGEN, AND SULFUR VALUES VALUES OF FEATHERS FROM  200 HUNTER-HARVESTED INDIVIDUALS IN THE SDJVS FEATHER ARCHIVE AND COMBINE THEM WITH EXISTING ISOTOPE DATA FROM 120 HUNTER-HARVESTED INDIVIDUALS. BIRDS TO BE USED IN THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WERE KILLED ACROSS THE ATLANTIC, MISSISSIPPI, AND PACIFIC FLYWAYS AND FEATHERS WERE COLLECTED AT WING BEES IN THE U.S. AND CANADA. ISOTOPE DATA WILL BE STATISTICALLY ANALYZED AND USED ALONGSIDE MAPS OF BREEDING RANGES TO ADDRESS OUR PROPOSED OBJECTIVES. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS COST-EFFECTIVE AND WILL HELP (1) DESCRIBE THE BROAD-SCALE DISPERSAL PATTERNS OF JUVENILE SEA DUCKS AND (2) DELINEATE BREEDING GROUNDS FOR LONG-TAILED DUCKS AND SURF SCOTERS. WE BELIEVE THAT THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL BE RELEVANT TO CONSERVATION AGENCIES AND WILDLIFE MANAGERS THAT FACE PRESSING QUESTIONS RELATED TO POPULATION DELINEATION AND HARVEST OF SEA DUCKS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO CONTINUE A LONG STANDING RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE RWBJV AND THE NEBRASKA  COMMUNITY FOUNDATION (NCF). THIS COLLABORATION WILL UTILIZE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FROM USFWS MIGRATORY BIRDS AND  OTHER USFWS DIVISIONS ALONG WITH NCF S FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT SKILLS TO SUPPORT THE RWBJV PARTNERSHIP IN ACHIEVING  THE BIRD HABITAT CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN THE IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AND ASSOCIATED ANNUAL OPERATION  PLANS. THE ANNUAL OPERATION PLANS PROVIDE ANNUAL GOALS THAT IF INCREMENTALLY IMPLEMENTED WILL CONTRIBUTE  ACHIEVING THE ULTIMATE GOALS OUTLINED IN IMPLEMENTATION PLAN. THIS AGREEMENT STRUCTURED AS AN INCREMENTAL  AGREEMENT TO ALLOW ANNUAL CONTRIBUTIONS TO ACHIEVE THE ANNUAL GOALS. TO SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENT MIGRATORY BIRD  HABITAT CONSERVATION THE RWBJV PARTNERSHIP DEVELOPED ITS IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AROUND THE SHC FRAMEWORK AND JV  MATRIX. THE RWBJV IMPLEMENTATION PLAN HAS FIVE INTERRELATED CRITICAL ELEMENTS  JV ADMINISTRATION, BIOLOGICAL  PLANNING, CONSERVATION DESIGN, RESEARCH MONITORING EVALUATION, AND IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT DELIVERY. THIS  AGREEMENT WILL UTILIZE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LEGISLATION FUNDING FOR AGREEMENT ADMINISTRATION AND  IMPLEMENTATION OF PROJECTS TO ADDRESS WOODY ENCROACHMENT.  TO ENSURE EFFECTIVE OPERATIONS (JV ADMINISTRATION), FUNDING WILL BE PROVIDED TO SUPPORT OFFICE MANAGEMENT,  OVERHEAD, ADMINISTRATION AND CONTRACT DEVELOPMENT FOR REMOVAL OF WOODY ENCROACHMENT IN GRASSLANDS.  THE FOCUS OF THIS WORK WILL BE TIED TO REMOVAL OF WOODY ENCROACHMENT FROM INTACT GRASSLANDS. RECENT REMOTE  SENSING PROJECTS HAVE HIGHLIGHTED A SIGNIFICANT ENCROACHMENT OF WOODY SPECIES INTO GRASSLANDS. GRASSLAND BIRD  POPULATION DECLINES HAVE BEEN SIGNIFICANT AS RESULT OF THE WOODY ENCROACHMENT. THE APPROACH TO GRASSLAND  CONSERVATION HAS SHIFTED BECAUSE OF THIS ENCROACHMENT. THE NEW FOCUS IS ON DEFENDING THE REMAINING CORE  GRASSLANDS BY ADDRESS SEED SOURCES AND CONTROLLING WOODY SPECIES AT ULTRA LOW DENSITIES TO AVOID ENCROACHMENT.  THE FUNDS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS AGREEMENT WILL ENSURE WE CAN MAINTAIN AND INCREASE THE GRASSLAND CORES THAT EXIST  ON U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE REFUGE SERVICE LANDS.  TO PROJECT DELIVERY WILL BE COMPLETED THROUGH CONTRACTS WITH LOCAL CONTRACTORS TO MECHANICALLY REMOVE WOODY  SPECIES IN GRASSLANDS WITH A FOCUS ON EASTERN RED CEDAR. THE FOCUS OF THESE FUNDS WILL BE ON THE NATIONAL FISH  AND WILDLIFE REFUGE UNITS ASSOCIATED WITH THE SANDHILLS REFUGE COMPLEX AND WATERFOWL PRODUCTION AREAS WITHIN THE  RAINWATER BASIN WETLAND MANAGEMENT DISTRICT. THE FUNDING PROVIDED BY THIS AGREEMENT SHOULD SUPPORT APPROXIMATELY  15,000 ACRES OF CLEARING ANNUALLY WITH A POTENTIAL OVERALL FOOTPRINT OF 125,000 ACRES OVER THE DURATION OF THIS  AGREEMENT IF FUNDED AT THE AWARD CEILING.

FUNDING FROM THIS AGREEMENT SUPPORTS THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY JOINT VENTURE (SFBJV) OVER A 5 YEAR PERIOD. ONE OF AN INTERNATIONAL NETWORK OF USFWS MIGRATORY BIRD JOINT VENTURES SPANNING MUCH OF THE NORTH AMERICAN CONTINENT, THE SFBJV COORDINATES A NON REGULATORY, SELF DIRECTED PARTNERSHIP, GUIDED BY AN IMPLEMENTATION PLAN THAT OUTLINES CLEAR HABITAT CONSERVATION GOALS TOWARDS WHICH THE PARTNERSHIP WORKS. WITH ONGOING THREATS TO HABITAT AND WILDLIFE, COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION EFFORTS ARE KEY TO IMPLEMENTING EFFECTIVE SOLUTIONS TO THE SCALE AND SCOPE OF CHALLENGES WE FACE. SINCE INCEPTION IN 2001, THE SFBJV HAS PROTECTED, RESTORED, AND ENHANCED OVER 70,000 ACRES OF WETLAND HABITATS, DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED INNOVATIVE PARTNERSHIPS, DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS, AND COLLABORATIVE PROGRAMS.SFBJV STAFF WORKS CLOSELY WITH PARTNER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF CONSERVATION ACTIONS, INCLUDING RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF VITAL WETLAND HABITATS THAT SUPPORT WILDLIFE SPECIES, INCLUDING WATERFOWL, SHOREBIRDS, AND OTHER WATER BIRDS. THE SFBJV WORKS ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF COORDINATED SCIENCE AND CONSERVATION DELIVERY THAT ADDRESSES KEY THREATS TO HABITAT AND WILDLIFE SUCH AS INVASIVE SPECIES, SEDIMENT DEFICITS, AND HABITAT CONVERSION AND DEGRADATION. THE SFBJV ALSO CREATES DECISION SUPPORT AND OTHER PRACTICAL TOOLS THAT ADVANCE CONSERVATION ACTION. FINALLY, THE SFBJV ROBUST COMMUNICATIONS WORK KEEPS PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS INFORMED AND ACTIVELY ENGAGED IN THE WORK OF THE PARTNERSHIP.FUNDING GOES TO SUPPORT THE STAFF TIME AND ACTIVITIES, ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS, SUPPLIES, AND CONTRACTS NEEDED TO RUN THE PROGRAM TO MEET THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE SFBJV IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY. PLEASE SEE PROJECT NARRATIVE FOR DETAILS.THIS IS A 5 YEAR INCREMENTALLY FUNDED PROJECT EXPECTED TO COST AROUND  2,850,000 OVER THE PROJECT PERIOD. FUNDING FOR SUBSEQUENT INCREMENTS IS SUBJECT TO THE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS, PROGRAM AUTHORITY, SATISFACTORY PERFORMANCE, AND COMPLIANCE WITH AWARD TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

THE "2020 NAWMP COMMUNICATION STRATEGY" WAS ENDORSED BY THE PLAN COMMITTEE IN SEPTEMBER 2020 AND IDENTIFIES FOUR  KEY ISSUES: (1) DECREASED FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR JOINT VENTURES AND NAWMP INFRASTRUCTURE, (2) CONCERNS EXPRESSED  IN RELEVANT REPORTS ABOUT INSUFFICIENT COMMUNICATIONS ABOUT NAWMP, (3) POLITICAL CHALLENGES RESULTING FROM LACK  OF UNDERSTANDING ABOUT NAWMP THAT EXISTS AT ALL LEVELS-FROM GOVERNMENT LEADERS TO DUCK HUNTERS, AND (4) THE  LOOMING DECLINES IN WATERFOWL POPULATIONS. FURTHERMORE, THE STRATEGY HAS TWO MAIN GOALS: (A) DELIVERING ENGAGING  AND EXPANDED COMMUNICATION WITH CONSERVATION AGENCIES; AND (B) ENGAGING THE WATERFOWL AND CONSERVATION  COMMUNITIES ABOUT NAWMP SCIENCE AND POLICY ISSUES.  THE CRITICAL NEXT STEP REQUIRED TO BUILD OUT AND IMPLEMENT THE STRATEGY IS TO IDENTIFY AND/OR DEVELOP A  COMPREHENSIVE PACKAGE OF MARKETING AND COMMUNICATION ASSETS. THIS ELEMENT OF THE PROJECT IS UNDERWAY AND IS  FUNDED BY THE CANADIAN WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND IN-KIND CONTRIBUTIONS FROM STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES. IN THE  CURRENT PROPOSAL, THESE IDENTIFIED ASSETS WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP A MARKETING STRATEGY, INCLUDING KEY MESSAGES  FOR PARTNERS TO USE AND CHOOSE AT EVERY "NEWSY" OPPORTUNITY. IDENTIFYING EXISTING MARKETING ASSETS AND  IDENTIFYING POTENTIAL ADDITIONAL ASSETS REQUIRES A CREATIVE CONSULTANT TO LEAD A SMALL TEAM OF PEOPLE  KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT NAWMP. THE CONSULTANT WILL PROVIDE EXPERT ADVICE AND REACH OUT TO THE MANY NAWMP PARTNER  ORGANIZATIONS TO ASSIST IN DEVELOPING RECOMMENDATIONS ON HOW BEST TO USE THE EXISTING MARKETING RESOURCES AND TO  DEVELOP A BOLD, NEW MARKETING PLAN AND NEW MARKETING ASSETS TO REACH THE TARGET AUDIENCES. THE MARKETING PLAN  WILL INCLUDE SUCH ITEMS AS PRODUCT REQUIREMENT DEFINITIONS, PROTOTYPE SPECIFICATIONS (I.E., BRAND GUIDE), AND  OTHER KEY ELEMENTS THAT WILL ENABLE THE NAWMP COMMUNITY TO REVITALIZE OR BUILD OUT THE NAWMP BRAND TO THE  PROPOSED TARGET AUDIENCES.

MIGRATORY BIRD JOINT VENTURES ARE COLLABORATIVE, REGIONAL PARTNERSHIPS OF GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, NON-PROFIT  ORGANIZATIONS, CORPORATIONS, TRIBES, AND INDIVIDUALS THAT CONSERVE HABITAT TO BENEFIT PRIORITY BIRD SPECIES,  OTHER WILDLIFE, AND PEOPLE. FIRST DEVELOPED TO IMPLEMENT THE NORTH AMERICAN WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT PLAN AND ADDRESS  DECLINES OF WATERFOWL, JOINT VENTURES NOW DELIVER THE FULL SPECTRUM OF CONSERVATION FOR WATERFOWL, LANDBIRDS,  SHOREBIRDS, AND WATERBIRDS. CURRENTLY, THERE ARE TWENTY-TWO HABITAT JOINT VENTURES, AND EACH ADDRESSES THE MOST  IMPORTANT BIRD HABITAT CONSERVATION ISSUES FOUND WITHIN ITS GEOGRAPHIC AREA.  THE APPALACHIAN MOUNTAIN JOINT VENTURE (AMJV) HAS THE FOLLOWING PRIORITIES AND GOALS FOR THE CALENDAR YEARS  2023-2027, ESTABLISHED IN THE AMJV STRATEGIC PLAN TO BE APPROVED BY THE AMJV MANAGEMENT BOARD IN 2022 AND  SUBSEQUENT REVISIONS.  IN ORDER TO FOSTER DYNAMIC AND HEALTHY FOREST LANDSCAPES, THE PARTNERSHIP WILL INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF OUTCOMEBASED MONITORING OCCURRING IN THE AMJV, INCLUDING CITIZEN SCIENCE-BASED EFFORTS. WE WILL ALSO ENHANCE AND  INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF STRATEGIC HABITAT DELIVERY WITHIN THE AMJV TO MAXIMIZE OUR CONSERVATION IMPACTS ON THE  GROUND. IT WILL BE CRITICAL TO PROMOTE AMJV BIRD CONSERVATION PRIORITIES THROUGH IMPROVED INTEGRATION OF THE  CONSERVATION INITIATIVES ACROSS THE AMJV (E.G., FIRE LEARNING NETWORK, SPRUCE RESTORATION INITIATIVES, SWAP  CONSERVATION AREAS, ETC). THE AMJV PARTNERSHIP WILL WORK TO ESTABLISH A STRONGER LINKAGE OF OUR CONSERVATION  ACTIVITIES WITH PARTNERS AS WELL AS LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO ADVANCE OUR CONSERVATION PRIORITIES, AND WILL CULTIVATE  BROADER COMMUNITIES OF INTEREST WITH A SHARED PURPOSE AND VISION. AMJV WORK IS RECOGNIZED AND SUPPORTED BY STATE/ FEDERAL AGENCY LEADERSHIP AND CONGRESSIONAL OFFICES WITHIN THE AMJV GEOGRAPHY.  AMJV ALSO HAS GOALS AND PRIORITIES OUTLINED WITH REGARDS TO BIRDS' FULL ANNUAL CYCLE. THE PARTNERSHIP WILL WORK  TO ADVANCE UNDERSTANDING OF BREEDING AND WINTERING GROUND LINKAGES AND MIGRATORY PATHWAYS FOR AMJV HIGHEST  PRIORITY SPECIES. WE WILL ALSO INCREASE WORK IN CRITICAL LOCATIONS TO IMPROVE SCIENCE AND MONITORING FOR AMJV  PRIORITY SPECIES. AMJV WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS TO PRODUCE EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE FULL ANNUAL CYCLE CONSERVATION  PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS, AND WILL NOT ONLY IMPROVE COMMUNICATION ABOUT INTERNATIONAL EFFORTS BY THE AMJV  PARTNERSHIP, BUT WILL ALSO IMPROVE GENERAL AWARENESS OF THE NEED FOR FULL ANNUAL CYCLE CONSERVATION.

THE ATLANTIC COAST JOINT VENTURE (ACJV) IS A REGIONAL PARTNERSHIP THAT COLLABORATES TO RESTORE AND SUSTAIN NATIVE  BIRD POPULATIONS AND HABITATS THROUGHOUT THE ACJV REGION. THE ACJV IS COMPRISED OF 16 STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES  FROM MAINE TO FLORIDA AND THE TERRITORY OF PUERTO RICO; FEDERAL AND REGIONAL HABITAT CONSERVATION AGENCIES; AND  OTHER ORGANIZATIONS THAT SHARE OUR VISION. THE PARTNERSHIP IS CURRENTLY FOCUSED ON ONE OF THE MOST IMPERILED  HABITATS IN THE ACJV REGION - COASTAL MARSHES AND THE SUITE OF VULNERABLE BIRDS THAT DEPEND ON THEM. THE ACJV IS  LEADING A COORDINATED MARSH RESTORATION AND PROTECTION EFFORT ACROSS THE FLYWAY TO ENSURE THAT THE PARTNERSHIP  CAN ACHIEVE ITS VISION. THE 2017 PPJV IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AND 2022 STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS PLAN OUTLINE DETAILED OBJECTIVES FOR ACHIEVING THE GOALS OF THE PPJV. WITH THE VAST MAJORITY OF LAND ACROSS THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE REGION HELD IN PRIVATE OWNERSHIP, IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT PPJV PARTNERS BUILD TRUST WITH RANCHERS BY SHOWING HOW MIGRATORY BIRD CONSERVATION AND GRAZING CAN COEXIST AND THRIVE. BY FURTHERING ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE NEXT GENERATION OF NORTH DAKOTA AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS, THE PPJV AND THE NORTH DAKOTA GRAZING LANDS COALITION (NDGLC) WILL CONSERVE MIGRATORY BIRDS AND OTHER WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN HEALTHY, WORKING GRASSLANDS.THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF EXPANDING THE INFLUENCE OF NDGLC THROUGH INCREASED FIELD CAPACITY AND FUNDING FOR ON-THE-GROUND CONSERVATION EFFORTS ON PRIVATE LAND TO WORK WITH INTERESTED LANDOWNERS. THIS INCLUDES TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO DEVELOP GRAZING PLANS AND INFRASTRUCTURE TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT ON WORKING GRASSLANDS. ADDITIONALLY, THE NDGLC WILL PROVIDE OUTREACH AND EDUCATION AS THE POINT OF CONTACT FOR TECHNICAL GRAZING AND LAND MANAGEMENT QUESTIONS AND BUILD PARTNERSHIPS WITH OTHER CONSERVATION AND AGRICULTURAL ENTITIES.

THE RIO GRANDE JOINT VENTURE (RGJV) IS A PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP OF ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALSCOLLABORATING ON STRATEGIC CONSERVATION OF BIRDS AND THEIR HABITATS. WE WORK IN THE CHIHUAHUAN DESERT ANDTAMAULIPAN BRUSHLANDS BIRD CONSERVATION REGIONS OF TEXAS AND NORTHERN MEXICO, AND THE GULF COASTAL PRAIRIE BIRDCONSERVATION REGION IN MEXICO. BY COOPERATING TO ENSURE THAT THE ECOSYSTEMS ACROSS THE BINATIONAL RGJV GEOGRAPHYSUPPORT THRIVING AND DIVERSE COMMUNITIES OF BIRDS, OTHER WILDLIFE, AND PEOPLE INTO THE FUTURE, THE RGJV PARTNERSDIRECTLY AND EFFICIENTLY SUPPORT THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE'S (USFWS) PRIORITIES FOR ITS MIGRATORY BIRDMANAGEMENT PROGRAM.THE RGJV IS GOVERNED BY A MANAGEMENT BOARD CHAIRED BY TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) AND WITHREPRESENTATION FROM USFWS, NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE, COMISION NACIONAL DEAREAS NATURALES PROTEGIDAS, COMISION NACIONAL PARA EL CONOCIMIENTO Y USO DE LA BIODIVERSIDAD, BIRD CONSERVANCY OFTHE ROCKIES, PRONATURA NORESTE, AMERICAN BIRD CONSERVANCY, DIXON WATER FOUNDATION, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY,AUDUBON TEXAS, DUCKS UNLIMITED MEXICO, WORLD WILDLIFE FUND, AND PASTICULTORES DEL DESIERTO, A.C. THE RGJV ALSOHAS TWO TECHNICAL TEAMS WITH REPRESENTATION FROM THESE ORGANIZATIONS, AS WELL AS PRIVATE LANDOWNERS,CORPORATIONS, AND UNIVERSITIES. THANKS TO THE WORK OF EXISTING AND NEW STAFF, AND ALL OF OUR PARTNERS, THE RGJVIS RAMPING UP TO BUILD SIGNIFICANTLY ON PROGRESS ACHIEVED OVER THE PAST FEW YEARS.SINCE 2008, THE RGJV MANAGEMENT BOARD, OTHER PARTNERS, AND STAFF HAVE ACHIEVED LONG-TERM AND LASTING CONSERVATIONGAINS FOR PRIORITY BIRDS, POLLINATORS, AND OTHER WILDLIFE BY COORDINATING THEIR EFFORTS TO ACHIEVE MORE TOGETHERTHAN ANY ORGANIZATION COULD ACHIEVE ALONE. THE RGJV IS INTEGRATING BIOLOGICAL PLANNING, CONSERVATION DESIGN ANDCONSERVATION DELIVERY, INCLUDING FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO LAND AND WATER STEWARDS, WITH MONITORINGAT LARGE SCALES TO ENABLE OUR PARTNERS TO LEVERAGE CONSERVATION INVESTMENTS AND INCREASE EFFICIENCY ANDEFFECTIVENESS. THE INVESTMENTS BY ALL THE PARTNERS OF THE RGJV CONTRIBUTE TO THE USFWS'S ABILITY TO MEET THEIRTRUST RESPONSIBILITIES, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES, AND INTERNATIONAL TREATY COMMITMENTS FORCONSERVING MIGRATORY BIRDS. IN ADDITION, CONTINUED INVESTMENTS TO ENSURE HEALTHY BIRD POPULATIONS PROVIDERECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR BIRD-WATCHING, PHOTOGRAPHY, HUNTING, AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS THAT BENEFITLANDOWNERS, BUSINESSES, AND COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE RGJV GEOGRAPHY. THE RGJV BUILDS RELATIONSHIPS WITH PARTNERS TOFACILITATE STRATEGIC INVESTMENTS IN CONSERVING ECOSYSTEMS FOR THE BENEFIT OF BIRDS, OTHER WILDLIFE, AND PEOPLE.THE RGJV IS CRITICAL FOR MEETING CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES FOR MANY SPECIES OF CONTINENTAL IMPORTANCE AS DETAILEDIN THE RECENT PARTNERS IN FLIGHT CONTINENTAL PLAN (ROSENBERG ET AL. 2016). THE RGJV GEOGRAPHY PROVIDES HABITATSFOR 17 WATCH LIST SPECIES THREE RED LEVEL AND 14 YELLOW LEVEL - AS WELL AS 10 COMMON SPECIES IN STEEP DECLINE.RGJV IS A HIGHLY IMPORTANT AREA FOR MANY OF THESE SPECIES IN NEED OF IMMEDIATE AND SUSTAINED CONSERVATIONATTENTION ATTENTION.WITH CONTINUED SUPPORT FROM THE USFWS, THE RGJV WILL CONTINUE TO FACILITATE SUCCESSES IN COORDINATED ANDCOLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION EFFORTS ACROSS THE 63 MILLION ACRES OF THE RGJV REGION. SPECIFICALLY, EVEN AS THE RGJVCONTINUES TO MEET OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN THE CURRENT (2018-2022) STRATEGIC PLAN, IN FY2022 THE RGJV WILL BEGINWORK ON A NEW 5-YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN THAT WILL GUIDE WORK FROM 2023-2027 WHILE CONTINUING TO IMPLEMENT IDENTIFIEDHIGHEST PRIORITY ACTIONS FOR BIRD CONSERVATION IN THE GRASSLANDS, RIPARIAN AREAS, AND WETLANDS ACROSS OURGEOGRAPHY.

THE OAKS AND PRAIRIES JOINT VENTURE (OPJV) IS A VOLUNTARY, NON-REGULATORY PARTNERSHIP OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE  ORGANIZATIONS, AND INTERESTED IN STRATEGICALLY COORDINATED CONSERVATION OF BIRDS AND THEIR HABITATS IN THE OAKS  AND PRAIRIES AND EDWARDS PLATEAU BIRD CONSERVATION REGIONS (BCR) OF CENTRAL TEXAS AND OKLAHOMA. THE OPJV MISSION  IS TO PLAN FOR AND FACILITATE BIRD HABITAT CONSERVATION, RESEARCH, AND OUTREACH IN AN EFFORT TO ENSURE  SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OF PRIORITY BIRD SPECIES IN THE EDWARDS PLATEAU AND OAKS AND PRAIRIES BCRS IN OKLAHOMA  AND TEXAS.  SINCE 2008, THE OPJV PARTNERS, MANAGEMENT BOARD, AND STAFF BUILT MANY TOOLS AND SUPPORT PROGRAMS TO CREATE  LASTING CONSERVATION GAINS FOR PRIORITY BIRD POPULATIONS WHILE HELPING TO INCREASE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES IN  THE OPJV REGION. USING THE OPJV IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AND THE DESIRED CHARACTERISTICS OF HABITAT JOINT VENTURE  PARTNERSHIPS MATRIX, THE OPJV HAS MADE GREAT STRIDES IN COORDINATING VOLUNTARY CONSERVATION EFFORTS OVER A LARGE  AREA SUPPORTING PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND PARTNER ORGANIZATION STAFF BIOLOGISTS AND LAND MANAGERS. OUR STAFF AND  PARTNERS HAVE SECURED OTHER PARTNER INVESTMENTS AND GRANTS FOR CONSERVATION EFFORTS, PROJECT MONITORING,  RESEARCH, AND PLANNING BY LEVERAGING FEDERAL FUNDING FOR BASE OPERATIONS.  AS A PARTNERSHIP, WE FULLY IMPLEMENT STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION FOR PRIORITY GRASSLAND BIRDS, INCLUDING  MAKING SIGNIFICANT STRIDES TO FACILITATE ON-THE-GROUND, LOCALLY-LED, VOLUNTARY CONSERVATION. OPJV STAFF WORKS TO  ORGANIZE INDIVIDUALS AND PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS INTO LOCAL INITIATIVE TEAMS THAT WORK ACROSS STATE, FEDERAL AND  NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS TO PROVIDE HIGH QUALITY TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS INTERESTED IN  CONSERVATION EFFORTS. PARTNERS COLLABORATE TOGETHER TO FACILITATE AND FUND A GRASSLAND RESTORATION INCENTIVE  PROGRAM (GRIP). THE GRIP HAS ALREADY PROVIDED SUPPORT TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS FOR HABITAT IMPROVEMENT WORK ON OVER  112,000 ACRES SINCE IMPLEMENTATION IN NOVEMBER 2013, AND IS FUNDED LARGELY BY STATE AND PRIVATE SOURCES,  INCLUDING TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE UPLAND GAME BIRD STAMP FUND, NFWF MONARCH BUTTERFLY AND SPIRIT OF CONSERVATION  FUNDS FOR LARGE SCALE GRASSLAND HABITAT ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION PROJECTS. WE ARE ON TRACK TO IMPROVE AT LEAST  60,000 ACRES DURING THE 2017-2022 PERIOD THROUGH A $6.1 MILLION RCPP PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT WITH USDA-NRCS  PARTNERS.  NUMEROUS OTHER LANDOWNER COOPERATIVES AND PRIVATE LANDS CONSERVATION DELIVERY EFFORTS ARE ALSO SUPPORTED BY OPJV  PARTNERS, DEMONSTRATING A SIGNIFICANT COMMITMENT TO RESTORING THESE RESOURCES IN A STRATEGIC MANNER. WITH  CONTINUED SUPPORT THROUGH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, THE OPJV CAN CONTINUE TO MAKE STRIDES IN VOLUNTARY,  COORDINATED CONSERVATION EFFORTS ACROSS THE 66.5 MILLION ACRES OF THE OAKS AND PRAIRIES JOINT VENTURE REGION.

THIS AGREEMENT WILL SUPPORT SOUTH DAKOTA GRASSLAND COALITION LEADERSHIP AND STAFF CAPACITY TO WORK WITH  INTERESTED LANDOWNERS AND CONSERVATION PROFESSIONALS TO EXPAND EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS. SDGC WILL WORK  CLOSELY WITH OTHER PARTNERS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A WIDE VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS AND PRODUCTS.  PRIMARY DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A SERIES OF RANCHING STEWARDSHIP VIDEOS, COMMERCIALS HIGHLIGHTING GRASSLAND  VALUES, A SERIES OF FEATURE-LENGTH MAGAZINE ARTICLES, AND SUPPORT FOR LOCALLY-LED RANCH TOURS. IN ADDITION,  BASED ON PARTNER NEEDS, THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT MAY ALSO SUPPORT THE ANNUAL SD GRAZING SCHOOL, THE ANNUAL SD  GRASSLAND PLANNER, AND THE YOUNG ADULT RANCHING FOR PROFIT SEMINARS. THIS MULTI-YEAR INCREMENTAL FUNDING  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL BEGIN IN 2022 AND CONCLUDE IN 2024.

THE PLAYA LAKES JOINT VENTURE (PLJV) STAFF AND BOARD HAVE IDENTIFIED NINE AREAS OF TOP IMPORTANCE IN THE  MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF BIRD SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS IN OUR REGION. THESE FOCUS AREAS - CONSERVATION  DELIVERY, BIOLOGICAL PLANNING, COMMUNICATIONS, GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS, FUNDING, GRANTING, EDUCATION,  RESEARCH, AND ANNUAL REVIEW - COMPRISE THE FOUNDATION OF OUR ORGANIZATION, AND ALLOW US TO BUILD STRONG, MUTUALLY  SUPPORTIVE AREAS OF EXPERTISE THAT ELIMINATE CONSERVATION DELIVERY BOTTLENECKS. FOR EXAMPLE, BIOLOGICAL PLANNING  CANNOT BE EFFECTIVE WITHOUT RESEARCH; RESEARCH IS INEFFECTIVE UNLESS RESULTS ARE COMMUNICATED TO LAND MANAGERS  AND LOCAL CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIPS (LCPS); AND LCPS AND LAND MANAGERS CANNOT IMPLEMENT PROJECTS WITHOUT FUNDING  AND PROGRAMS TO SUPPORT THEIR WORK. REMOVING THESE BOTTLENECKS REQUIRES A MAJOR COORDINATION EFFORT WHICH WE  PROPOSE TO CONTINUE UNDER THE PARTNERSHIP MODEL PLJV HAS REFINED OVER THE LAST 33 YEARS THROUGH FUNDING FROM THE  U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AS WELL AS FROM ITS STATE AND REGIONAL PARTNERS.

SEA DUCKS CONSTITUTE A MARINE BIRD VITAL SIGN INDICATOR OF ECOSYSTEM HEALTH IN THE SALISH SEA, WHICH IS OF GLOBAL IMPORTANCE TO MANY POPULATIONS OF MARINE BIRDS THAT USE DIFFERENT PARTS OF THEECOSYSTEM THROUGH THE COURSE OF EACH ANNUAL CYCLE. IT IS IMPERATIVE TO WORK ACROSS MANAGEMENT JURISDICTIONS TO EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE OR RECOVER KEY AREAS OF HABITAT FOR THESE BIRDS. HOWEVER, THE JURISDICTIONAL COMPLEXITY PRESENTS A MAJOR CHALLENGE TO TAKING AN ECOSYSTEM SCALE APPROACH TO THE PROBLEM, NOT LEAST BECAUSE MANY INFORMATION SOURCES (I.E., BIOLOGICAL DATASETS) END AT THE INTERNATIONAL BORDER. WE AIM TO OVERCOME THIS BARRIER BY HARMONIZING INFORMATION IN A WAY THAT ASSISTS THE AGENCIES RESPONSIBLE FOR IMPLEMENTING CONSERVATION PRESCRIPTIONS, ESPECIALLY IN TERMS OF KEY HABITATS. IN DOING SO, OUR PROJECT WILL ELEVATE SEA DUCK NEEDS INTO CONSERVATION PLANNING PROCESSES, THROUGH CONVENING A NETWORK OF SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS FROM BOTH CANADIAN AND U.S. JURISDICTIONS OF THE SALISH SEA.TO ACHIEVE OUR OBJECTIVE, WE WILL IMPLEMENT A THREE-PHASE PLAN TO LEVERAGE A RANGE OF EXISTING RESOURCES FOCUSED AROUND TWO SEA DUCK HABITAT SUITABILITY MODELING INITIATIVES, ONE IN BRITISH COLUMBIA AND ONE IN WASHINGTON. IN PHASE 1, WE WILL ENGAGE A GROUP OF EXPERIENCED ANALYSTS WORKING ON SEA DUCKS AND THE HABITATS THAT SEA DUCKS USE, TO IDENTIFY AND ASSESS COMPATIBILITY OF RELEVANT BIRD AND ENVIRONMENTAL DATASETS, AND ASSESS LONG-TERM SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL CORRELATIONS BETWEEN BALD EAGLES AND PRIORITY SEA DUCK SPECIES. WHILE THIS IS TAKING PLACE, WE WILL REACH OUT TO THE RESPONSIBLE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES TO UNDERSTAND HOW WE CAN INTEGRATE SEA DUCK HABITAT VALUES INTO SIX LINKED PLANNING PROCESSES THAT PRESENT OPPORTUNITIES TO IMPROVE CONSERVATION OF SEA DUCK HABITATS. IN PHASE 2, WE WILL CONVENE BOTH ANALYSTS AND CONSERVATION MANAGERS AT AN IN-PERSON WORKSHOP TO FINALIZE THE CHOICE OF DATA LAYERS AND RECOMMEND A UNIFIED APPROACH TO MODELLING SEA DUCK HABITAT AT THE SCALE OF THE SALISH SEA ECOSYSTEM. IN PHASE 3, WE WILL COMPLETE DETAILED PREPARATION OF THE DATA LAYERS FOR INCLUSION IN THE SEA DUCK MODEL(S), MAKE THEM AVAILABLE IN A GEODATABASE ACCOMPANIED BY A TECHNICAL REPORT DESCRIBING THE DATA INTEGRATION FRAMEWORK FOR THE MODEL(S), AND DELIVER A WEBINAR TO THE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES FOCUSED ON HOW PROJECT AND MODEL OUTPUTS CAN BEST INFORM CONSERVATION PLANNING.BIRDS CANADA WILL FACILITATE THE PROJECT, TAKING RESPONSIBILITY FOR ENGAGING AND COORDINATING THE NETWORK OF ANALYSTS AND AGENCY LEADS, ORGANIZING THE WORKSHOP AND FOLLOW-UP WORK. OUR ANALYSTS WILL PREPARE THE DATASETS AND SUPPORT COLLABORATORS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON, WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, AUDUBON WASHINGTON, ENVIRONMENT AND CLIMATE CHANGE CANADA, FISHERIES AND OCEANS CANADA AND DUCKS UNLIMITED CANADA. BIRDS CANADA WILL TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR ENGAGING CONSERVATION PLANNING PROCESS LEADS IN CANADA AND WASHINGTON CO-INVESTIGATORS WILL TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR ENGAGING MANAGEMENT AGENCY LEADS ON THE U.S. SIDE.

OVERABUNDANT LIGHT GOOSE (SNOW AND ROSS'S) POPULATIONS AND THEIR IMPACTS ON HABITAT AND OTHER
SPECIES ARE A TOP AGJV RESEARCH PRIORITY AND A MANAGEMENT AND REGULATORY FOCUS OF THE USFWS. THIS 
PROJECT WILL ASSESS DEMOGRAPHIC RATES OF SNOW GEESE ALONG WESTERN HUDSON BAY, CANADA AND EVALUATE 
SNOW GOOSE IMPACTS ON HABITATS AND OTHER GOOSE AND WILDLIFE SPECIES. PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS WILL 
MARK SNOW GEESE, ROSS'S GEESE, AND CANADA GEESE WITH LEG BANDS TO MONITOR DEMOGRAPHIC RATES, 
MONITOR ABUNDANCE AND NESTING/PRODUCTIVITY AT SNOW GOOSE COLONIES, AND MONITOR HABITAT, VEGETATION, 
AND OTHER ABIOTIC FACTORS. FIELDWORK WILL OCCUR IN MANITOBA AND ONTARIO, CANADA. RESULTS FROM THIS 
PROJECT WILL HELP IMPROVE EXISTING MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT APPROACHES FOR LIGHT GEESE AND WILL 
HAVE IMPLICATIONS ON FUTURE HARVEST REGULATIONS AND CONSERVATION PLANNING IN THE UNITED STATES AND 
CANADA.

THE INTERNATIONAL BLACK DUCK ADAPTIVE HARVEST MANAGEMENT STRATEGY IS BASED, IN PART, ON ESTIMATES OF BLACK DUCK PRODUCTIVITY AS MEASURED BY 
ADJUSTED FALL AGE RATIOS.  ADJUSTED FALL AGE RATIOS ARE CALCULATED USING PRE-SEASON BANDING RECORDS, HUNTER REPORTED RECOVERIES OF BANDED 
BIRDS, AND PARTS COLLECTION INFORMATION.  IT IS HYPOTHESIZED THAT BLACK DUCK PRE-SEASON BANDING OPERATIONS MAY NOT ADEQUATELY REPRESENT THE 
BLACK DUCK BREEDING POPULATION DUE TO THE LOCATIONS AND TIMING OF BANDING OPERATIONS.  IT IS POSITED THAT BIRDS NESTING IN THE NORTHERN PART
OF EASTERN CANADA MAY MIGRATE LATER THAN BIRDS THAT NEST IN SOUTHERN CANADA AND OR OVER-FLY SOUTHERN CANADA MAKING THEM UNAVAILABLE FOR BANDING.
IF NORTHERN NESTING BIRDS HAVE DIFFERENT PRODUCTIVITY THAN SOUTHERN NESTING BIRDS ESTIMATES OF PRODUCTIVITY MAY BE BIASED.  THIS PROJECT WILL
USE STABLE ISOTOPE ANALYSIS OF AMERICAN BLACK DUCKS HARVESTED IN SOUTHERN CANADA AND THE UNITED STATES TO DETERMINE IF THE ORIGIN OF THE BIRDS
IS SIMILAR BETWEEN THE TWO SAMPLES.  IF THE SAMPLES INDICATE SIMILAR ORIGINS THE HYPOTHESIS OF BIAS WILL BE DISCOUNTED, IF THE SAMPLES ARE 
DIFFERENT IT MAY INDICATE A POTENTIAL BIAS AND NEED FOR FURTHER RESEARCH.

BLACK BRANT ARE A TOP ARCTIC GOOSE JOINT VENTURE RESEARCH PRIORITY. RECENT SURVEYS AND
DEMOGRAPHIC STUDIES INDICATE CONFLICTING INFORMATION ABOUT POPULATION STATUS AND TREND. THIS
PROJECT WILL MARK BLACK BRANT IN ALASKA WITH GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM (GPS) SENSORS TO
EVALUATE MIGRATION PHENOLOGY AND HABITAT UTILIZATION. NEW QUANTITATIVE METHODS WILL BE
DEVELOPED TO ESTIMATE BLACK BRANT POPULATION SIZE USING HARVEST AND RECOVERIES OF BANDED BRANT
COLLECTED AT HUNTER CHECK-OUT STATIONS ALONG THE PACIFIC COAST. MOST ANALYSES WILL BE CONDUCTED IN
COLORADO, NEVADA, AND ALASKA. RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE INFORMATION ON BLACK BRANT
DEMOGRAPHIC RATES, MIGRATION PATTERNS, HABITAT USAGE, AND POPULATION SIZE AS WELL AS ADVANCE NEW
AND COST-EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE MONITORING TECHNOLOGIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE THE FEASIBILITY OF A LONG-TERM COLOR MARKING AND RESIGHT PROGRAM FOR ATLANTIC BRANT, WHICH WILL ALLOW FOR IMPROVED MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF THIS SPECIES.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO PROVIDE A BIOLOGICAL TEAM LEADER STAFF POSITION, RESPONSIBLE FOR LEADING THE PARTNERSHIP'S WATERFOWL SCIENCE ACTIVITIES, TO THE GULF COAST JOINT VENTURE.

GULF COAST JOINT VENTURE BIOLOGICAL TEAM LEADER: THE GULF COAST JOINT VENTURE MANAGEMENT BOARD CREATED A BIOLOGICAL TEAM LEADER (BTL) POSITION TO COORDINATE CONSERVATION PLANNING, EVALUATION AND RESEARCH ACTIVITIES TO INFLUENCE STRATEGIC DELIVERY OF PRIORITY WATERFOWL HABITAT CONSERVATION WITHIN THE GULF COAST JOINT VENTURE GEOGRAPHY.  THE BIOLOGICAL TEAM LEADER PERFORMS THESE DUTIES AND WORKS TOWARD: 1) UPDATING THE GCJV BIOLOGICAL PLANS AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES TO REFLECT NEWLY AVAILABLE SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION; 2) ORGANIZING AND CHAIRING A WATERFOWL WORKING GROUP THAT PROVIDES TECHNICAL GUIDANCE ON PRIORITY CONSERVATION AND SCIENCE IN SUPPORT OF WATERFOWL HABITAT OBJECTIVES; AND 3) DESIGNING AND ASSISTING EVALUATION AND RESEARCH ACTIVITIES IN THE GCJV REGION.  THE ABOVE NEEDS ARE CRITICAL TO FACILITATING EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT CONSERVATION DELIVERY IN THE GCJV REGION AND MEETING OBJECTIVES OF THE NAWMP.

THE NORTH AMERICAN WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT PLAN (NAWMP) COMMITTEE RECOGNIZED THE NEED TO HAVE CONTINUING SUPPORT AND LEADERSHIP TO GUIDE THE ONGOING INTEGRATION
EFFORT BY THE WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY TO ACHIEVE GOALS, OBJECTIVES, AND PRIORITY ACTIONS OF 2018 NAWMP UPDATE.  THIS WORK BUILDS ON SIGNIFICANT
INTEGRATION ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF THE NAWMP INTERIM INTEGRATION COMMITTEE (IIC) THAT WAS IN PLACE TO IMPLEMENT ASPECTS OF THE 2012 NAWMP REVISION AND ACTION PLAN.
SPECIFIC WORK WILL INVOLVE ENGAGEMENT WITH THE WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY TO ADVANCE INTEGRATION, THROUGH COMMUNICATION AND INVOLVEMENT, AS PRIORITY WORK
ITEMS ARE ADDRESSED BY EXISTING AND AD HOC COMMITTEES AND WORKING GROUPS (E.G., HUMAN DIMENSIONS WORK GROUP, HARVEST MANAGEMENT WORK GROUP, NAWMP 
SCIENCE SUPPORT TEAM, FLYWAY COUNCILS, JOINT VENTURES, ETC.).

SINCE 1962, THE USFWS HAS COOPERATIVELY CONDUCTED THE WATERFOWL DIARY SURVEY AND PARTS COLLECTION SURVEY TO ESTIMATE HARVESTS OF WATERFOWL. MANAGERS HAVE RAISED CONCERNS ABOUT POTENTIAL INACCURACY OF GOOSE HARVEST ESTIMATES. THIS PROJECT WILL INCORPORATE GENETIC ANALYSES AND DEVELOP NEW QUANTITATIVE METHODS TO REFINE PARTS COLLECTION SURVEY SAMPLING PROTOCOLS AND IMPROVE HARVEST ESTIMATES OF ROSS'S, SNOW, CACKLING, AND CANADA GEESE. A SIMULATION STUDY WILL BE CONDUCTED TO EVALUATE HOW DIFFERENT DATA SOURCES BIAS ESTIMATES OF POPULATION SIZE BASED ON THE LINCOLN ESTIMATOR, AND AN ANALYSIS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO SHOW THE COST-BENEFIT TRADE-OFFS ASSOCIATED WITH IMPROVING ACCURACY AND VARIANCE OF THE ESTIMATES. DATA FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE COLLECTED FROM GEESE HARVESTED IN ALL U.S. STATES VIA THE USFWS PARTS COLLECTION SURVEY. MOST GENETIC AND QUANTITATIVE ANALYSES WILL OCCUR IN FORT COLLINS, COLORADO.
